title: How to force myself to read a boring book - Quora

response.answer_text: Sometimes the same old advice is the one you should avoid. I think this is one of those times... (No offense folks!) Dividing into chunks can make reading feel like you're walking through Dante's Inferno. Don't count and track the pages. Instead, read as many pages as you can before becoming totally disinterested on day 1. The next day, read the same amount as the day before +2 pages. Repeat until you've finished the book. If you have a deadline you are worried about meeting, change your daily increase amount. Why does this work?Because you are training your attention span, and you'll be surprised by how much you can get through each day. If you fall short one day you won't have to worry about catching up. Just try to beat yourself the next day by at least 2 pages. I wrote some tips here that I find essential for reading and would swear by: Val Mack's answer to What are the correct ways of reading a book? Reading strategies or techniques.TLDR: Read and take notes like you are going to write a review on it later. If you are reading a novel and writing is too much work, pretend you're just giving TMZ or Rotten Tomatoes like commentary (or "Watch What Happens Live" on Bravo). Criticize every underwhelming plot twist, every dry attempt at humor, and every disgustingly obvious use of foreshadowing. This makes reading MUCH easier in my experience.

Read one sentence. One sentence, that’s all. The next day, read one sentence. The day after, read one sentence. Day day after that, read one sentence. Etc. Etc. Etc. If you read one sentence then you won the entire day. Do not judge, just congratulate yourself. Eat an M&M immediately after to reward yourself. Now if you finished reading that sentence and want to read some more? Perfectly okay. If you end up reading for 5 hours or just stick to that one sentence, it’s all good. This is how to build the habit of reading (or anything). -Daniel  PS. If you want strategies on how to be more powerful in life check out my blog: Declare War Within. I would read the beginning, then read the end, then work towards the middle. (Divide the number of pages by the number of days you have to read it. Read that many pages a day.) This might make it more interesting since you could see what the author is leading up too.     I did that with Moby Dick, in my opinion the most boring book in the world. And I did well in the test over it. I still do that with books I don't like.  There is not enough time in the world to waste any on a book I don't like.

Break it down into manageable chunks... Look at how long you have got to read it and then divide the number of days by the number of pages... Give yourself a minimum count to read a day... Try and do that minimum count in one sitting... If you read more, don't fall into the trap of giving yourself time off or less to read the next day, always do the minimum... You never know, you might actually get motivated... But if not, you have a plan to get to the end.

Skim. Skip over the parts you find not worth the effort to read.  Even the greatest masterworks usually contain large expanses of excess detail or outright cruft.  Nobody is going to offer you extra credit for reading every word. So go ahead and cull the chaff.  It's the wheat you'll remember anyway.
Take your time and read only a chapter or two then stop and do something else for a while. Then go back and read another chapter or two and repeat. Eventually you'll get through the book.
